TEXT1: It is not currently known whether MAO inhibitors or the metabolite of furazolidone affects amphetamine metabolism.
MAO inhibitors and MAOI antidepressants slow amphetamine metabolism, as does a metabolite of furazolidone.
If you're taking antihistamines, be aware that amphetamines may reduce the sedative effect of the antihistamines.
Amphetamines may counteract the sedative effect of antihistamines.
It is not recommended to take amphetamines with antihistamines, as the amphetamines may counteract the sedative effect of the antihistamines.
It is not known whether amphetamines may reduce the effectiveness of antihypertensives in lowering blood pressure.
Other drugs that lower blood pressure may reduce the effectiveness of amphetamines.
If you are taking antihypertensive medication, please be aware that amphetamines may counteract the effects of these drugs.
Chlorpromazine can help to reduce the central stimulant effects of amphetamines by blocking dopamine and norepinephrine receptors. This makes it a possible treatment for amphetamine poisoning.
Chlorpromazine can be used to treat amphetamine poisoning by blocking dopamine and norepinephrine receptors and inhibiting the central stimulant effects of amphetamines.
Chlorpromazine may help to reduce the central stimulant effects of amphetamines, by blocking dopamine and norepinephrine receptors. Therefore, it may be useful in treating amphetamine poisoning.
Chlorpromazine can help to counteract the central stimulant effects of amphetamines by blocking dopamine and norepinephrine receptors.

Chlorpromazine works to block dopamine and norepinephrine receptors, which can help to reduce the central stimulant effects of amphetamines. This medication can be used to treat amphetamine poisoning.

Ethosuximide: Amphetamines may decrease the rate of intestinal absorption of ethosuximide.
Ethosuximide: Amphetamines may slow down the intestinal absorption of ethosuximide.
If ethosuximide and amphetamines are used together, the absorption of ethosuximide may be delayed.
Haloperidol blocks dopamine receptors, which can inhibit the central stimulant effects of amphetamines.
The blocking of dopamine receptors by haloperidol may inhibit the central stimulant effects of amphetamines.
If you take haloperidol, it may block the dopamine receptors and inhibit the central stimulant effects of amphetamines.
The anorectic and stimulatory effects of amphetamines may be inhibited by lithium carbonate.
It is possible that the anorectic and stimulatory effects of amphetamines may be hindered by lithium carbonate.
The concomitant administration of lithium carbonate and amphetamines is not recommended, as the stimulatory effects of amphetamines may be inhibited by lithium carbonate.
Meperidine and amphetamines may enhance each other's effects, so it is best to avoid using them together.
Amphetamines appear to potentiate the analgesic effect of meperidine, though it is not clear how or why this occurs.
Meperidine: Amphetamines can enhance the pain-relieving effect of meperidine.
The use of methenamine therapy alongside amphetamines may reduce the effectiveness of the latter.
If you are taking methenamine therapy, please be aware that urinary excretion of amphetamines is increased. Additionally, the efficacy of methenamine therapy is reduced by acidifying agents.
Methenamine therapy can interfere with the efficacy of amphetamines by increasing their urinary excretion.
Norepinephrine: Amphetamines may enhance the adrenergic effect of norepinephrine.
Amphetamines are known to enhance the adrenergic effect of norepinephrine, which may cause increased blood pressure and heart rate.
Norepinephrine and amphetamines may enhance each other's effects.
Amphetamines may delay the absorption of phenobarbital in the intestine.
Phenobarbital: Amphetamines might delay intestinal absorption of phenobarbital;
There is a possibility that amphetamines may slow down the intestinal absorption of phenobarbital; however, this has not been definitively proven.
Taking amphetamines may delay the intestinal absorption of phenytoin.
If you are taking phenytoin, please be aware that Amphetamines may delay the intestinal absorption of the drug.
It is possible that amphetamines may delay the intestinal absorption of phenytoin; however, this has not been definitively proven.
Propoxyphene: In cases of propoxyphene overdosage, amphetamine CNS stimulation may be potentiated and fatal convulsions could occur.
If propoxyphene and amphetamine are used together, the central nervous system stimulation caused by the amphetamine can be potentiated, which may lead to fatal convulsions.
In cases of propoxyphene overdosage, CNS stimulation from amphetamine is increased and can lead to fatal convulsions.
Veratrum alkaloids: Amphetamines may reduce the hypotensive effect of veratrum alkaloids.
It is not known for certain whether amphetamines inhibit the hypotensive effect of veratrum alkaloids due to the presence of veratrum alkaloids or hyperuricemia in these patients.
If antihistamines are taken together with other CNS depressants such as barbiturates, tranquilizers, and alcohol, additive CNS depression may occur.
CNS depression may occur when antihistamines are administered together with other CNS depressants, including barbiturates, tranquilizers, and alcohol.
Concurrent use of antihistamines with other CNS depressants such as barbiturates, tranquilizers, and alcohol may result in additive CNS depression.
Additive CNS depression may occur when antihistamines are administered concomitantly with other CNS depressants including barbiturates, tranquilizers, and alcohol.
It is not recommended to use flurbiprofen and aspirin concurrently.
If you are taking both flurbiprofen and a beta-blocker, it is recommended that you be monitored closely to make sure that your blood pressure stays at a satisfactory level.
A possible drug interaction of FOSCAVIR and intravenous pentamidine has been described.
